summary: This is a news article from ABC News' 'The Blotter' blog dated July 26, 2006, reporting that arrest warrants were prepared for Jeffrey Epstein's assistant Sarah Kellen and associate Nadia Marcinkova in connection with the Florida investigation. It details allegations against them, including procuring underage girls for massages, and notes the state attorney's office closed the case after a grand jury indicted only Epstein on lesser charges, with police referring the matter to the FBI.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: The New York financier charged in a sex scandal; the investigation focused on allegations he paid for underage girls to be brought to his house for massages that turned sexual.

persons.name: Sarah Kellen
persons.context: Arrest warrants were prepared for her as a principal on multiple counts related to unlawful sexual activity with minors; alleged to have prepared massage tables and called girls when Epstein was in town.

persons.name: Nadia Marcinkova
persons.context: Arrest warrants were prepared for her for lewd and lascivious acts on a victim under 16; pictured in the article and alleged to have been paid by Epstein to bring over young girls.

persons.name: Barry Krischer
persons.context: The State Attorney for Palm Beach County who declined to send the case against Kellen and Marcinkova to a grand jury, leading to the closure of the state's investigation.

persons.name: Brian Ross
persons.context: ABC News reporter credited with the 'Blotter' report on the Epstein case.

connections.description: Kellen was Epstein's assistant, alleged to have facilitated his activities by preparing massage areas and contacting girls.
Marcinkova was allegedly paid by Epstein to bring young girls to his house for massages.
Arrest warrants were prepared for both in connection with the investigation into Epstein's activities, suggesting alleged coordinated roles.
As State Attorney, Krischer's office made the decision not to pursue charges against Epstein's associates and later closed the state case.

events.title: Police interview of Nadia Marcinkova
events.description: Nadia Marcinkova was interviewed by police in October 2005, where she admitted to bringing six girls, ages 15 to 18, to Epstein's home for massages and was paid $200 per girl.

events.title: Arrest warrants prepared for associates
events.description: In May 2006, police submitted arrest warrant requests for Sarah Kellen and Nadia Marcinkova for their alleged roles in Epstein's activities.

events.title: News report on warrants and case closure
events.description: ABC News reports that arrest warrants were prepared for Epstein's associates, but the state attorney's office closed the case after a grand jury indicted only Epstein on a single prostitution charge.

events.title: Palm Beach Police investigation
events.description: The Palm Beach Police Department conducted an investigation into Epstein in the summer of 2005 and had been urging the case to go forward.

events.title: Grand jury indictment of Epstein
events.description: A grand jury indicted Jeffrey Epstein for solicitation of prostitution, a single charge, leading the state attorney to close the case regarding his associates.

keyFacts: Arrest warrants were prepared in May 2006 for Sarah Kellen and Nadia Marcinkova for their alleged roles in Jeffrey Epstein's underage sex ring, but were never executed.

The State Attorney's Office, under Barry Krischer, declined to pursue the charges against Kellen and Marcinkova, closing the state's investigation after a grand jury indicted only Epstein on a single prostitution charge.
Police documents allege Kellen prepared massage tables and called girls when Epstein was in town, while Marcinkova admitted to bringing girls aged 15-18 to Epstein's home for $200 each.
The Palm Beach Police Department had completed its investigation in the summer of 2005 and wanted the case to proceed, but the state attorney's office ended its involvement.
The matter was referred to the FBI after the state case was closed, indicating a shift to federal jurisdiction.
